thread.title: UK GAS-Prices gain as rising demand widens supply deficit
thread.title_full: UK GAS-Prices gain as rising demand widens supply deficit

title: UK GAS-Prices gain as rising demand widens supply deficit
text:
* Dutch gas imports collapse to zero 
* Within-day gas prices increase 
July 9 (Reuters) - British prompt gas prices extended gains on Thursday as a supply shortfall grew, with generators burning more gas to produce electricity and imports from the Netherlands falling to zero. 
Reduced wind and nuclear output helped lift gas demand. 
Gas for immediate delivery rose nearly 1 percent to 44.45 pence/therm by 1001 GMT and gas for Friday traded unchanged at 44.15 p/therm. 
Britain's gas network was undersupplied by 27 million cubic metres/day (mcm), or more than 14 percent of current demand estimated at 190.8 mcm, according to National Grid (LSE: NG.L - news ) data. 
"Short supplies again this morning are seeing prompt contracts firm from Thursday," Marcel Boonaert, head of trading and portfolio at Wingas UK, said. 
"Rising wind forecasts offering the potential for lower gas to power (demand) and warmer temperature outlooks going into next week could see contracts pressured as the session progresses," he added. 
Imports from the Netherlands through the BBL sub-sea link dropped to zero, from around 7 mcm on Wednesday. 
Deliveries from BP's Dimlington Easington terminal stayed at zero for a second day. 
Output from the UK Continental Shelf was 3 mcm below expected levels at 113 mcm. 
Further out on the curve, the benchmark winter 2015 gas contract was up 0.20 p/therm at 47.15 p/therm. 
Gas for winter 2015 delivery edged 0.05 pence higher at 47.20 p/therm. 
Dutch day-ahead gas at the TTF hub was up 0.20 euro at 20.75 euros per megawatt-hour. 
Europe's benchmark carbon price was unchanged at 7.46 euros per tonne on ICE Futures Europe. (Reporting by Oleg Vukmanovic in Milan; Editing by Dale Hudson)
